Definition: Determine whether or not the given comment is Obscene. Any depiction or description of sexual topics that offends moral principles is referred to as obscenity.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Guess Barron needs to babysit the dummy and supervise his tweets.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is unrelated to pornography or obscenity.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Shut up nerd. You try too hard.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic but is not obscene.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Sailors found whores and coke.I'm shocked!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: "This vitriolic politics crap needs to end pretty damned soon . . ."  Couldn't agree more. It's severely damaging the country, and has been for years. But you seem to give Trump a pass for his partisan behavior, policies, and the obvious falsehoods that come out of his mouth. You seem to just blame and ridicule anyone who questions or is critical of Trump's policies and behavior. And given Trump's performance and behavior to date, I think there is a lot to question and criticize. Maybe, just maybe, the problem is with Trump, not so much with his critics. 
Criticism, just to get your name in the news, or to only score partisan political points undermines democracy. But I expect and want thoughtful, well reasoned criticism from our other officials when they think the country is going down the wrong path. That's democracy, and loyalty to country before loyalty to party or any one individual. Be that individual Trump or anyone else.

  The only good news about Hep A is that if you have already had it, you are "immune" and likely can't get it again.  ( Source  http://www.sfcdcp.org/hepatitisa.html  )   Denver experienced a local "epidemic" of Hep A in 1970.   I remember it very "un-fondly."  Damn near killed some of us.

It won't be pretty.   Regards, Gary

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

Comment: The Legislature fiddles while the state burns.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: WTH did people think was going to reduce all the various forms of pollution, and its consequences?
Did they think the Pollution Fairy was going to drop by one night and make it all go away?

For generations we have lived like spoiled brats on this planet--& we continue to do so.
We buy useless & wasteful & unnecessary things that even our parents',& certainly our grandparents' generations, would be horror-stricken by. How many vehicles? 'Entertainment centres'? See-doos? Leaf-blowers? Disposable diapers? Plastic bags?

How many tons of natural resources do those things consumer? Wood, precious metals, energy to obtain them, manufacture them, ship them, advertise them, sell them, dispose of them?

For decades we have known that there is no place on the planet that has entirely clean air, clean water, or clean soil.
And we have given not one single damn, for our children or their children. The latest toy or outfit has been more important.

Suck it up buttercup--the bill is long past due.

Comment: We do love the Church. If we didn't, we would have left years ago. We reject YOUR idea of the Church, but that's something else entirely. 

We think that abandoning "orientation, liturgical language, liturgical music" is a good thing. Having the priest stand with his back to the congregation, mumbling in a language most of the laity do not speak, is a terrible way of having a communal worship service. Religious music is one of the best examples of "Sturgeon's Law" I know of (the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon was told, "Ninety percent of sf is crud", to which he replied "Ninety percent of EVERYTHING is crud".) Yes, today's music also exemplifies Sturgeon's Law.

BTW, Montanism was not condemned solely for having women priests. It was largely condemned for its theological beliefs. Your statement is simplistic at best.

We think about the teachings. If they give us good arguments, we accept them. Crap gets rejected. The arguments against ordaining women are crap, for example.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

I also firmly believe that the income tax should be graduated and there should be about 20 levels of graduation.  When the rich are drafted into the military to be infantry, artillery, combat engineer, and armor privates, then they can pay the same tax rate as those individuals earning $11,770 or less per year.  https://aspe.hhs.gov/2015-poverty-guidelines

Bottom line, any debate about taxes and the tax system that doesn't simplify and make the tax system so transparent that an Oregon high school graduate can understand it; is nothing more than more of the same, increasing the local, state, and national debt.

Comment: Mark Rozman - I'm curious - how exactly are mountain bikers getting a "free ride at your expense?"  Do YOU pay an annual fee for construction and maintenance of new and existing trails - besides taxes - which we ALL pay?  I don't think so.  On a related note, local mountain bike clubs all across the country provide a tremendous amount of volunteer trail work each year on state, county, city and federal lands.  Ask any public lands manager.  Finally, in Breckenridge 0.5% of all local sales tax goes to fund area trails - so the 500 Breck Epic racers who spent 6 days and nights in Breckenridge contributed thousands of dollars to the construction and maintenance of the local trail system in a single week - just in local taxes on lodging and food.  Finally, the Breck Epic this year raised over $3,000 in direct contributions to the local trail system in an impromptu raffle on the final day.

Comment: If you over simplify, as I think Ms. Hayes has, it's pretty plain. No one person, president, senator, congressman, etc, can overturn an amendment to our Constitution. So to flesh out the concerns of Second Amendment people, should supreme court justices resign during the next administration, and judges placed into that court who oppose the Heller decision, it is quite likely that gun control advocates will file suits that will go all the way to the supreme court and the court will reverse itself. The right to keep and bear arms will then become a collective rather than an individual right.

Comment: The Jays - rightly or wrongly - gave Edwin one offer, take it or leave it, within 48 hours of EE's qualification for free agency.

No reasonable agent would jump on the first offer, especially given the peculiar timing of it.

If you were selling your house, would you take the first offer? No, of course not.

If you're buying a car, would you work with the dealership (or person) that said, "This is the price, take it or leave it"? I highly doubt it.

Alas, this is the "new normal" in negotiations. You see it in real estate all the time now. "Bully offers" - here's my offer, there's no discussion, you have 24 hours or less to decide - are the norm, not the exception. Salary discussions are all about "This is what we're paying. If you don't like it, there's the door." Examples abound.

The electoral college is an antiquated system that has not even demonstrated the benefits that its creators believed it would deliver. It does not "protect" less populated states. Rather, it shifts the entire focus of presidential elections to a handful of so-called battleground states while the rest of the country - and its needs - are pretty much ignored.

Comment: I'm not a big fan of either, but I've seen both, if you can count the first three Star Wars movies and a random smattering of different Star Trek episodes as having seen them. 

Of course you have an apples and oranges problem in making the comparison, because the scope of the two projects – objectives, budgets, people involved, and all things creative – were so different. Trek was conceived to sell ads on network TV, right? Wars was a Lucas/Spielburg extravaganza. Sure, Trek became a series of movies too, but that was afterthought. So it bothers me that you cite history based on the movies with Star Wars first, when Star Trek actually started almost two decades earlier than Star Wars, in 1966, as a television show. 

Production values, star power, effects, of course all go to Star Wars, and there is budget and objectives behind that. But Star Trek did start earlier, paved the way, and had a long history of different people involved, with an interesting flair for putting real human problems (racism, for example, a recurring theme in Star Trek as the different races dealt with each other) into a new perspective. And there's interesting comparisons on the big picture, too ... the great Yoda perspective and quotes, of course, and the whole power of the force, in Star Wars. But Trek embraced big picture too, like the larger collective metaphor of Seven of Nine. 

I wish you'd done a straight compare and contrast, instead of which is better. Better will always be subjective, and it's too close ended, in my opinion.

Comment: Here's what the Constitution actually says:  Section 8.1 - Statement of Policy:
It is the policy of the State to encourage the settlement of its land and the development of its resources by making them available for maximum use consistent with the public interest.  Section 8.2 - General Authority: The legislature shall provide for the utilization, development, and conservation of all natural resources belonging to the State, including land and waters, for the maximum benefit of its people.   Here's what the law establishing the fund actually says:  AS 37.13.020:  (1) the fund should provide a means of conserving a portion of the state's revenue from mineral resources to benefit all generations of Alaskans.   You'll not find the word "individual" anywhere.  Because the laws say that the mineral rights belong to, and are to be managed for, the citizens of Alaska, present and future, collectively.   Nobody invested a single dime for which they are entitled to a return by a dividend.

Comment: From the OECD: "Income inequality has reached record highs in most OECD countries. In the 1980s, the richest 10% of the population had 7 times the income of the poorest 10%; they now have almost 10 times the income of the poorest 10%.Wealth is even more concentrated in OECD countries than income.  In 2012, the bottom 40% owned only 3% of total household wealth in OECD countries for which data are available.  By contrast, the top 10% controlled half of all total household wealth and the wealthiest 1% owned 18%."

It seems Ms. Paris, you forgot the other lessons of history: Economic and political inequality. Comment: The explanation in the article makes no financial sense. HTDC is funded with state tax dollars as an investment in the state economy. The need and reason for grant-in-aid is understandable but the efforts to use it in a behind-the-curtains method is something they do in Oz, not for Hawaii.  HTDC is a state corporation but trying to bureaucratize startups is something a state government would do.  It would be better if HTDC decided what the state needed, then invested in projects to provide local employment. The point is create a local hi-tech employment environment, not make somebody successful to relocate to Silicon Valley.  The way HTDC is operating is very passive, almost like sugar cane leaning in the wind. One area HTDC should be looking at is the massive failures in computer and engineering projects in Hawaii, like the total collapse of the DOT IT system.

Comment: No, C-42 did nothing of the sort. It is no easier to get a restricted firearm now than it was before C-42. C-42 does not loosen any restrictions on the locations that restricted firearms can be transported to.

Restricted firearms ownership has increased, the last numbers I saw were by about 10%.  This is largely attributed to the increased interest in competition events, like the 3-gun courses.  It's a target shooting challenge. As the name suggests, there are 3 guns used in the events, a shotgun, a rifle, and a handgun. The most common rifle used in the events is the AR-15, which is restricted. So, for everyone getting involved you have a restricted handgun, and most likely a restricted rifle. These are people just looking to enjoy their hobby.

You seem to have some misconceptions about this topic. I would recommend that you look up where your local firearms shop is, and make a trip down to talk to the people that work and shop there. I bet you'll find it very informative.

Comment: "Las Vegas hotel operators must make their guests feel valued and comfortable in the aftermath of the shooting, said Michael McCall, Michigan State University professor of hospitality business." 

What should be expected of casino, hotel and resort operators is an intelligent allocation of the security resources they already command.  I well recall the time I was patiently waiting in the lobby of a downtown Vegas hotel/casino for my room to be cleaned when I was approached by two armed security guards.  "Our video surveillance reported a 'sleeper' in the lobby - so get up and move along" the fatter of the two declared.  "Okay," I confessed, for I did indeed briefly rest my travel-weary eyes while stiffly seated in a waiting area about 20 feet in front of the hotel registration desk.  Move along I did - and haven't returned in the years since.

In the wake of the Mandalay Bay tragedy, one can only hope security personnel are deployed with, how shall I put it, more brains and finesse.

Comment: I HATE that Trump was elected, but apparently you don't understand how the electoral college works. 

There are 538 electors from the 50 states. That number is based on the number of Representatives for each state (435 total based on state population) + 2 for the 2 senators for each state + 3 for DC. In most states, a electoral college voter CANNOT vote "against the state majority" (even if the "majority" is only 51% - which means essentially 49% of the state's votes "didn't count") without repercussions (in some states civil, in others criminal). That's how a candidate can win the popular vote and still lose the election - and the electoral college voters have very little choice (although the Constitution doesn't "bind" them to casting ALL votes the same as the popular majority for that state, the STATES DO).

Comment: No both build on our nature.

Here's a better understanding/explanation for you. 

God can (and wants to) use our nature to help us to get closer to Him.

The human virtues are "strengths", capabilities that through the grace of God and our repetitive cooperation we can build to allow us to love more.  Virtues are habits of doing good acts.  Enduring dispositions but which can become derailed. 

Patience, prudence, cheerfulness (it's a strength too), industriousness, temperance, courage, fortitude...etc. 

Without these "tempering strengths" we can often "give in" to our nature which was injured by Original sin.  

We lost our perfect dominion of our attentive and appetitive faculties. 

That's why we need God.  And God allows us the dignity of growing in virtue. 

Virtues oppose vices (in fact particular virtues oppose particular vices). 

Virtues are in the middle of one or more of opposing vices.

Courage is "in the middle" of pusillanimity and recklessness (two vices). 

Etc.

Comment: Your claim that "it had nothing to do with the tax structure" was clearly and completely disproven by the "Reaganomics" changes in the tax structure. From 1951 (the end of the Marshall Plan) to 1981 (the beginning of the Reagan tax changes), both GDP and private sector jobs grew at an accelerating rate. See invisiblegoose.com for charts. For the same number of years after that change, growth in both GDP and private sector jobs slowed (and even went negative). 
.
There was no magic involved, and no sudden change in the world economies. In the earlier period, the combination of relatively high top-end tax rates, multiple progressive brackets, and generous targeted tax deductions provided a significant incentive to create jobs for American workers and to pay them well. While many jobs were offshored during that period, newly created jobs more than made up for them. The Reagan tax structure (and rate) changes crippled those incentives and investment in domestic job creation fell.

Comment: For the most part, I agree with you. Being respectful to one another is one thing. creating a repressive atmosphere is something else. Where I worked, "diversity" training at times went too far. I agreed with the stated goals - a more harmonious work place. But the way it was implemented, some people felt they were being lectured to and looked down on. At times, the training had the opposite effect. It inhibited people from getting to know each other and talk about things other than sports, the weather. etc. To question some of the "training", which I did at times, made you "suspect" and in the eyes of some, in need of yet more training (indoctrination?). Laughable, except for the fact that it was causing, as you say, further divisions among us.
There is discrimination in this country, and that needs to be addressed. But I think some folks look for a reason to be "offended" and a "victim", and that harms everyone, particularly those who really have been discriminated against.

Comment: Interesting.  I could see that up to a point, but it would depend on how close we're talking.  It doesn't make a lot of sense to build a toll road and then go build so much "free" capacity alongside that would keep people from using the toll road.  If you're going to do that, then there's no need for the toll road.

But we're NOT building that "free" capacity, making it kind of moot.  

I'd love it if we did finally increase road-dedicated funding so we could build more "free" road capacity around the metro area where it's needed.  But since we keep failing to do that, adding some toll roads is better than nothing.

I still think that if voters were given the chance to vote on a tax increase that's for ROADS ONLY (no transit, no bike paths, no other stuff), they'd pass it overwhelmingly. But we've yet to see such a measure on the ballot.

Comment: How do you reconcile the internal contradictions of your own commentary? What you now acknowledge as a 20% GHE contribution for CO₂ was alleged to be about 0% in one of your earlier comments. Well, some progress perhaps.

There has been no reliable trend in global cloudiness. There has been a reliable downward trend in snow/ice extent. The water vapor feedback (minus the lapse rate feedback) is positive. Double CO₂, get ~1ºC of warming and ~7% more water vapor, which adds to the initial warming. And the claim of GCM projections being "on the high side by about 300%" is completely nonsensical.

As someone so scientifically illiterate, you don't really have the luxury of sending anyone back to any drawing board.

Comment: First, America has one of the most regulated economies in the world.   Referring to America as the "free market" is both inaccurate and self-serving.   The last time America had extremely high growth and social mobility was in the 1930s-1960s, when taxes were their highest  EVER and when our democracy redistributed those resources in favor of the middle class.  Social Security, Medicare, and other widely popular programs are the fruits of social democracy.

Secondly, comparing social democracy to Maoism is not really fair.  Bernie Sanders is a democratic socialist, not a state socialist.  Government for the people, by the people, to benefit the people.  It's not Communism.  Mao and Stalin both were authoritarian dictators.  

Thirdly, is abolishing the 40 hour work week a "reform" you want?  How about those child labor laws?  Those all qualify as ways the government controls the free market, to the benefit of all of us.  

A choice telling of American history, to be sure.

Comment: He's specifically incorrect, but not far off base. I believe the Continental Army (which number 80,000 at the height of the war, never 1 million - the census of 1790 only found 205 million total population) was disbanded as part of the treaty of Paris in 1783. The Colonies ran their government under the Articles of Confederation up until 1789. The Legion of the United States did remain from 1783 to 1792 (when the Army was formed), primarily used to combat and remove Native Americans from their land.  So, yes, there was a small "standing army" but not for the purposes of defense from a large European aggressor.  The militias absolutely would have been called upon in such and event.  This was further evidenced in the War of 1812 when Madison call upon state militias to assist in invading Canada (many refused or fought poorly).

Anyway, while impercipient's statement isn't precise in detail, I think it is accurate enough for his argument.

Comment: Ah, angry duck honk is back. The Pac-12 rule effectively eliminates senior graduate transfers by its loss of a year's eligibility requirement. But wait . . . 
Grad transfers enrolled at their new school and practicing with their new team (Carrington is and has) can submit a waiver petition, which is obvious. Otherwise, why be there? Here's the fun part:
"If the institution from which the student-athlete is transferring does not support a reduction of the residence and/or eligibility requirements to their minimum levels, it shall inform the student-athlete in writing prior to the petition being presented to the Conference."
"Prior to" also means "before."
It's a Pac-12 matter now. Oregon's on board (no overturn option), just as Cal was when Brennan Scarlett grad-transferred to Stanford two years ago.
As for Adams, he also needed his release from EWU, just as Jalen Brown did before graduating Oregon this spring to transfer to Northwestern. It's how it works. You can look it up.

Comment: If your entire argument of "income splitting is bad" rests on the notion that it is not fair, you are standing on very shaky grounds. Practically every tax break in the code is available for one group at the expense of another. As a salaried person, you have access to many tax breaks that I don't have as a business owner - for example RRSPs. As a business owner, I use dividends, which don't generate RRSP contribution room. I also don't have a pension plan so I have to use passive investments for my retirement.The tax code has been designed to properly adjust for circumstances and risk taking. 

With regards to income splitting, it is only available to shareholders/owners of a private corporation. What the government is proposing is that some shareholders are not worthy of dividends and must now pay confiscatory tax rates. Do you think that is fair? Please explain why you think dividend payouts are "slimey".

Comment: No, I'm not suggesting that. 
Lets take the best case scenario: deductive logic is possible. Those with training in it - will get absolutely guaranteed results. 
Problem: those results are only as TRUE as the premises (the underlying data on which you are basing your conclusion).
If all the premises are true - your answer MUST be true.
If even one of the premises is false, your answer CANNOT be true.

So philosophy trained people are still, quite often, wrong - even in the best case scenario. Because we don't have perfect data, and even the selection of data for premises is not immune to human fallibility and biases.

The difference is - with the same data, the logic trained person will at least form an opinion that is, in fact, supported by and in accordance with that data.
They won't THINK the data supports a conclusion that it actually disproves. That step is not possible otherwise. Same data, a thousand conclusions - only one is logically correct.

Comment: Unfortunate, but true.  A 32%+ shock to labour costs will have the paradoxical effect of deepening the wage gap:  low-skill workers will have hours reduced or be laid off; diligent, skilled workers may see a boost (better value to give such a worker a boost in pay and duties), and the use of technology becomes far more attractive.

Does a business pay ~$100K/year fully encumbered for 3 minimum wage staff or buy a $75K machine once that doesn't call in sick, doesn't need leave and doesn't demand a raise.

Not every job is or should be intended for one to support a family.  Entry level roles are entry level for a reason.

Comment: I agree that there may be an issue of fairness when it comes to the distribution of dividends to family members and the conversion of income into capital gains.  These steps result in tax avoidance.  Have at them.  
However, taxation of passive income on retained earnings is short sighted.  There are a great many corporations that retain earnings in good years in order to cover costs, including employee salaries, in lean years.  
A business needs the ability to plan over longer periods of time.  It also seems logical to grow those retained earnings through investment.  Increased taxes on these retained earnings (some say 73%) will cause owners to take the earnings as larger income and pay their "fair share", while leaving less in the corporation. 
In the lean years, with less business revenue, the owner will resort to cost cutting and layoffs, or will borrow and assume risk in order to make payroll etc.  
The  unintended consequence may be fewer jobs for the "tax disadvantaged".

Comment: Scientific knowledge is the stuff of word definitions.
Wikipedia "Zygote" quotes: "A zygote is ... formed by a fertilization event between two gametes.  The zygote's genome is a combination of the DNA in each gamete, and contains all of the information necessary to form a new individual.  ... 
In human fertilization, two 1n haploid cells — an ovum (female gamete) and a sperm cell (male gamete) — combine to form a single 2n diploid cell called the zygote.  DNA is then replicated in the two separate pronuclei derived from the sperm and ovum, making the zygote's chromosome number temporarily 4n diploid.  After approximately 30 hours, fusion of the pronuclei and subsequent mitotic division produce two 2n diploid daughter cells called blastomeres.  ... 
The human zygote has been genetically edited in experiments designed to cure inherited diseases."
Wikipedia "Human development (biology)" quote: "Human development ... entails growth from a one-celled zygote to an adult human being."

 Re-read the article, it says that the PUBLIC voter lists, sans confidential information is "Routinely provided to political operatives and other groups". Been doing that as far back as in the early 1970's in Alaska. 
Try reading the federal laws regarding the National Voter Registration of 1993 , the Executive Order signed by Bill Clinton in 1994 implementing it, the Voter's Righrs Act, the HAVA of 2002 and the State of Alaska statues for clarification.
The US Department of Justice's web site has a lot of info as they are the folks who enforce the laws over voting and elections.As far as what I can tell, there is nothing in the federal statues that gives voters the right to privacy (other than their confidential information) with a few exceptions that I found under the NVR. If I go to apply for welfare and they ask me if I want to register to vote, and I say NO, that is confidential. If I say yes and they register me, where I registered (welfare office) is confidential.

Comment: When he drew his gun is not relevant. Any trial and conviction would not be based entirely upon statute law but case law as well. Here is a brief history. Prior to 1986 police mainly carried double action revolvers. There was a major shootout in Florida with the FBI where agents were killed because they ran out of ammo. After that occurred police starting carrying semiauto handguns. Police shootings occurred and many lawsuits filed because officers physically pulled the hammers back on there guns when train on a suspect. Juries determined the action of cocking the hammer amounted to declaring intent to kill. As a result departments started issuing hammerless guns without external safeties. The result is in a lawsuit filed today, the case is made that the mear pointing of the gun is intent because there is no safety on most guns police carry. These guns do not have the longer trigger pulls even tough they require more pounds of pressure then a single action with hammer back.

Comment: My original comment was a more general point about new New Left jargon that could apply equally to you, the author, and anyone else with an obstinate allegiance to their private dictionary. 

As to your example, most people can see why items in the business section have some relevance to their own lives. As such, in order to better engage with these items, it might behoove people to familiarize themselves with the jargon. Those who fail to do so might put themselves at a palpable disadvantage in financial affairs. Business jargon often tends to be quite lazy and is therefore easier to parse.

As for my own language, I am using relatively well-known terms that I find to be more precise and fit for purpose. Nevertheless, anyone with an Internet connection can unearth the meaning of an unfamiliar word in a matter of seconds.

Comment: What purpose does it serve to mandate rentals in a rezoning process, only to later allow those rentals to be converted to condos or other types of stratas. 

Here in Richmond city council is considering allowing Onni to rezone purpose built rentals in Steveston to a hotel.  Simply because Onni now wants to capitalize on selling the rental housing as strata hotel units.

It is all well and fine announcing plans and having intentions, but what sort of follow-up is there to ensure that ten years down the line (even five years!) developers (and the City) don't simply backtrack on plans and promises.

Same goes for low income rentals that are allowed to be sublet at market rates, or let at market rates after the first tenant moves out.  What, we don't officially talk about this, or keep proper stats?

There is "action", and then there is accountable verifiable action with proper control and follow-up.

But it seems we just have one without the other.

Comment: This article seems to ignore the fact that low interest rates create money at faster rates than high interest rates.  Money is created by lending, and M3 is one of the Bank of Canada measures of the money supply.  Inflation is defined as growth in the money supply, yet measured by prices.  If consumer prices are remaining stable, which they are, then asset price inflation is the best explanation the 7% annual growth in the money supply in Canada.  So what?  Interest rate rises will curb growth in the money supply and slow down asset price inflation.

Comment: "You are free to your opinion."

But it's not "my opinion" any more than it is "my opinion" that the Earth is not flat.  Science tells us what the facts are, and facts don't have opinions, nor do they require you to agree with them.   The Earth is still round even if you don't believe that it is, and voters are still ignorant even if that knowledge makes you feel uncomfortable.

"No matter what counter argument I provide, it will not change your perspective, and vice versa."

False, and that's what makes us fundamentally different.  My views are based upon facts, not feelings, emotions, or beliefs.  If you had some compelling data to demonstrate that voters are not ignorant, and it was better than the overwhelming mountain of evidence showing that voters are ignorant, I would change my position immediately.  Unlike you, I change my views as the information changes.  If it were proven that the Earth was actually flat, that would become my view.  I would change it, just like that.

The chemical structures for folate (5-methyltetrahydrofolate), folic acid and folinic acid are provided not far from the top of the page.

Some people lack an enzyme required to convert folic acid to folate, methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase.  

Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase catalyzes the conversion of 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate to 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, a cosubstrate for homocysteine remethylation to methionine.   Elevated homocysteine is a risk factor for heart disease that is well recognized among cardiologists.

People with anomalies of the MTHFR gene have trouble with this conversion and the problems can be severe.   Common issues include weight gain and symptoms of coeliac disease or "irritable bowel syndrome" as well as elevated risk for a wide range of health conditions such as heart disease.

It's best to avoid man-made folic acid in food when possible

Comment: That's a common misconception about tenured faculty. It depends on the department, college or university. Some tenured faculty are expected to publish a lot, whereas others are not expected to publish at all. I know of full professors who haven't published in a decade but have earned "honors" and "awards" and pay increases not contingent on publishing. Some are rewarded for other activities, or simply by the reputation they earned many years ago. Sometimes, like in any organization, there is favoritism, nepotism, etc.

The status of tenure is also changing with this new generation of faculty, as universities and colleges no longer have (and most can't financially sustain) as many tenured faculty as they once did. This coincides with the fact that the structure of higher education is also changing as online education is becoming more prominent and campus-based higher education is less necessary for delivering quality research and instruction to a wide audience anywhere.

Comment: "We need another and a wiser and perhaps a more mystical concept of animals. Remote from universal nature and living by complicated artifice, man in civilization surveys the creature through the glass of his knowledge and sees thereby a feather magnified and the whole image in distortion. We patronize them for their incompleteness, for their tragic fate of having taken form so far below ourselves. And therein we err, and greatly err. For the animal shall not be measured by man. In a world older and more complete than ours they move finished and complete, gifted with extensions of the senses we have lost or never attained, living by voices we shall never hear. They are not brethren, they are not underlings; they are other nations, caught with ourselves in the net of life and time, fellow prisoners of the splendor and travail of the earth."

 - Henry Beston, American writer-naturalist

Comment: Aktion, I would argue that it is pretty easy if you have the time and inclination. And the time need not be onerous - I hold 46 individual stocks and it's no big deal at all monitoring them (although if one is into speculative penny stocks, then that's a different kettle of fish).

My recommendation would be that you open a self-directed account with a discount broker (all of the big banks discount brokers are fine) and initially put a small amount of money into it and invest in some of the classic large cap dividend growth stocks. Comment: The mandate of the OSC is to protect depositors, borrowers, and the Canadian financial system, not the shareholders. Don't get me wrong, I am a strong believer in the stock market and a stock investor myself, but it would be grossly inappropriate for the OSC to act in the shareholders' interest. There was evidence, in the view of the OSC, of misrepresentation of risk on behalf of the very top management at Home Trust, and that information needs to be made public. Canadians demand near-absolute confidence in Canada's smaller lenders, and absolute confidence in the big 5. At that level, there are some mistakes that simply cannot be made. And if imposing such discipline means the shareholders bear the brunt of the discipline, that's their problem. Better that that information gets out now rather than ignore it until it gets really bad. If you don't like being a Home Trust shareholder, be glad you weren't a Bear Sterns shareholder.

Comment: You're using an Alberta royalty rate when prices were at their lowest.

When times are good with high oil prices the royalty rates are usually over 30% on top of their additional federal and provincial business taxes plus the GST to the federal government for the sale of the oil. 
Alberta oil companies have also been paying a provincial carbon tax since 2008 which most conveniently won't mention. 

Why won't you talk about the 32% royalty rate when oil prices are high that do pay for roads, bridges, schools, fire halls, police stations, bus stations, other transit stations, maintenance and repair, water purification, garbage collection, hospitals?

Comment: The thing about dual citizenship is that it often isn't the choice of the 'citizen'.  Some countries such as Iran and China do not allow you to renounce their citizenship. Comment: When I did Crow Pass in 2013, the water was above my waist. I had expected knee high water and wasn't prepared for how wide the crossing was. My two hiking partners and I teamed up with 2 other groups so there was 7 of us linking arms to do the crossing. It was going well until the dog of one of the other girls started getting swept away. She jumped for the dog and broke the chain. The one end of the chain started going down. It was pretty scary trying to regain balance when your feet are numb from the cold and there are large cobbles that move under your feet. In retrospect, I wouldn't cross it that high again but we had prepared for a long day hike not an overnighter. It is an epic hike but the river crossing was much more dangerous than I had imagined. Don't underestimate it and call the Eagle River Nature center to get River conditions before you go.

- Thus, the paperwork as burden is without merit.

Comment: In the nation’s first presidential election in 1789 and second election in 1792, the states employed a wide variety of methods for choosing presidential electors, including
● appointment of the state’s presidential electors by the Governor and his Council, 
● appointment by both houses of the state legislature, 
● popular election using special single-member presidential-elector districts, 
● popular election using counties as presidential-elector districts, 
● popular election using congressional districts, 
● popular election using multi-member regional districts, 
● combinations of popular election and legislative choice, 
● appointment of the state’s presidential electors by the Governor and his Council combined with the state legislature, and
● statewide popular election. 		
	
The winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes became dominant only in the 1830s

Comment: Do not so readily suppose that people coming out of PSU are into sustainability, any more than people coming out of Metro. There is a lot of parrot-thinking going on in those chambers, supporting growth as usual dressed as sustainability. 

What originated in the 60s and 70s as an in-depth, holistic approach to bringing our human populations and consumption down to within the carrying capacity of the local bioregion, through relocalizing our commerce — and thereby achieving prosperity, more greenspaces, and better quality of life for all — has been corrupted into  a machination for the haves to have more and the have-nots to get less, and for our neighborhoods to grow more overcrowded and more separated from nature. 

What originated as a bottom-up process has become a top-down process aided by the ivory tower views of academics and politicos, all congratulating each other on their progressive idealism even as we slide further into unsustainable existence ruled by non-local and elite capitalists.

Comment: Medical care is not affordable. While some can get by without, others have to choose between medicine and food. When that happens, health deteriorates as care gets postponed. That expense transfers to insurance. 

An important way to curb expenses is to diagnose earlier, before a diabetic loses his sight, a cancer is untreatable, etc. The insurance mandate was meant to appeal to more than actuaries and other financial wonks, but also to move us away from the expenses of emergency rooms providing routine care and people dying and being injured by neglecting their health.

I can't tell you how effective that effort has been. I suspect the insurance cost increases people are complaining about are smaller than they would have been without Obamacare. But the more important question is whether people have been saved from disabling conditions-- blindness, amputations, death -- by earlier awareness and intervention. I don't know if Obamacare helped with that either, but it is what counts.

Comment: In general, the longer someone serves on the bench, the better they get.  (Yes, there are a few exceptions.  But the selection of judges is pretty rigorous in the first place, so not too many.) 

Better how?  It's not that they know more law, it's that they get better and better boiling controversies down to their essentials, and seeing that only those essentials get the very expensive (to the public) remedy of a trial.  They also get better at avoiding rulings likely to be reversed (which is another big expense, if retrial is required).  Finally, the best (like Seaborn Buckalew, pbuh) grow in what we usually call "human understanding" as they spend their days working with parties who are not in court because it's a fun thing to do.  A courtroom sees a LOT of misery.  Good judges can radiate sympathy without partiality.

And they bad ones?  They get cynical and come to think they can't believe anything they hear.  I could mention names here, but they've passed on, too, so I'll refrain.

Comment: Virtually every person posting in this forum has reaped some of the benefits of illegal immigration. Do you eat meat or produce or processed foods? Ever spend time in buildings? Visit restaurants, hotels, or other places in the service industry? Enjoy domestic manufactured goods? All of these industries depend heavily on illegal labor, and of course we all like the low prices that labor helps to provide. Someone will inevitably argue this point, but the simple fact is that illegal immigration yields some benefits, no matter where your politics lie.

Virtually every person posting here suffers some negative impact from illegal immigration, too. Crime is a legitimate concern, as is providing public services to people who in many cases have not contributed their fair share of taxes. 

There are upsides and downsides, and illegal immigration isn't going away, so our focus should be on maximizing the upsides and minimizing the downsides. It's a shame we can't agree even on that.

Comment: I think we all likely have our own stories of Vets who were "let down" by the service providers who they (and we) trusted to support them when they came home.  Brian Babb is an extreme example of such a story and there are countless other cases which, while not so high-profile, are just as tragic.  

If we as a nation can't find ways to keep from putting our young men and women at risk in war, the very least we can do is to better serve them when they return.  We always seem to find the money and the means to fight those wars.  How about finding the money and the means to serve those returning young men and women whose lives and futures we jeopardized by sending them to fight those wars.  .  Is that asking for too much?

Comment: I'm not a fan of face coverings, but if a law is impractical to enforce, as Bill 62 appears to be, then it shouldn't be passed. If I was a bus driver in Quebec or any other public servant being expected to police people's attire in this way, I would refuse to do it. 

That being said, I think articles on the niqab/face veil issue tend to exaggerate the extent to which this attire represents women in the Muslim community. The proportion of Muslim women who cover their actual face is very small, so I think it's disingenuous to argue that legislation targeting them is an attack on all Muslims. A much larger number of Muslim women wear the hijab and no reasonable person has any objection to that form of Islamic garb.

It's also worth noting that the popularity of Islamic head gear of any sort varies from decade to decade and is therefore not a fundamental component of Islamic culture. If you see photos of Iranian or Turkish women in the 1970s, hardly any wore the hijab.

Comment: Ronni: The background check requires private individuals SELLING firearms to have potential buyers submit to the same background check which dealers require.  This keeps individuals who would fail that background check from purchasing weapons from private sellers; providing those sellers follow the law and require the check.  So the law, if followed, would force "criminals" and others who would fail the background check to purchase "illegally" from persons who are also willing to break the law.

It's clearly not "the" answer and no one has claimed it is.  It, if followed, does help.  Importantly, at the same time, it presents absolutely no threat to legitimate firearm owners.

 As many guns as we have in circulation it's probable that a criminal or other individual who would "misuse" the gun will find a way to get one.  However, that doesn't mean a law requiring private sale background checks won't help by making it more difficult.  regards, Gary Crum

Comment: "Military members disobey orders at their own risk. 

They also obey orders at their own risk. 

An order to commit a crime is unlawful. 

An order to perform a military duty, no matter how dangerous is lawful, as long as it doesn't involve the commission of a crime."

Articles 90, 91, and 92 of the UCMJ  

Ultimately, it's not whether or not the military member thinks the order is illegal or unlawful, it's whether military superiors (and courts) think the order was illegal or unlawful.

Manual for Courts Martial

"An order requiring the performance of a military duty or act may be inferred to be lawful and it is disobeyed at the peril of the subordinate. This inference does not apply to a patently illegal order, such as one that directs the commission of a crime."

Comment: A long time ago, in the 1960's-1970's my mother used to volunteer for a group called "Welcome Wagon" that used to contact new arrivals in Eugene and bring them presents, city information and coupons for local businesses.   At some point, some blacks moved to Eugene and the question in the organization (all white) was what to do with newly arrived blacks.  Would they get the same greeting?  Should they get the same welcome as white arrivals?  It made a very uncomfortable situation.  The majority view seemed to be that "Negroes" (the polite term at the time) would not be welcomed in the same way and  my mother left the program.  If anyone can resurrect a "Welcome Wagon" photo for a black family in the 60's to 70's I will be amazed and respond with admiration for the person who made it happen.

Comment: WOW! All one has to do to find this letter factual and agree with it is to completely ignore history .Take your misguided thinking on Reagan for example..we know for sure that we experience no gain in long-term tax revenue from increasing tax rates on those making more than $200,000 per year. Lower tax rates, particularly on labor and capital, lead to higher levels of employment and economic growth. 

The Reagan tax cuts reduced rates for all income classes, especially the low and middle income earner. Reducing the high marginal rates (up to 70% on high-income earners) causes little, if any, revenue loss, because of the large, positive supply-side effects.  by the time President Reagan left office, the economy was generating more tax revenue at a maximum 28% rate than many on the left forecast it to generate at a maximum 70% rate.
The Reagan tax-rate reductions did, in fact, pay for themselves — but it took about seven years.

Comment: The number of people who don't have a clue on this site is staggering. Loss carry froward is not paid by tax payers. It's expenses paid last year that exceed the allowable deductions for that tax year. 

Example. You have a job that pays $1000.00 in December but don't finish it until January. $700.00 was expense, $300,00 was profit. The entire expense is put on last year because that is when u spent the money for the job and the entire income is profit this year because that is when you billed it. But you reach the limit on deductions and can not deduct the $700.00 so it carries forward. 

You can only tax profits because the money they spend to make profits has already been taxed.

Comment: Adjusting the level of fluoride ions in community water is not consider "drug" delivery. (Nor is the addition of various water treatment chemicals. See Wikipedia on water treatment.)  

The optimal level of fluoride is a level found in nature, and many communities in the USA don't have to fluoridate simply because Mother Nature has blessed them with "just right" amount of fluoride in their ground water.  

As for the issue of "consent," informed consent is necessary for individual medical care.  Consent is not required for public health measures, because they must be demonstrated to be overwhelmingly safe and necessary for the safety and health of the community. For example, other public health measures include the requirement for infant car seats, restaurant hygiene, pasteurization, etc.

Comment: I was a Sears associate from 2007 to 2012, so I had front row seats for what was probably the most dramatic turn in Sears' decline - we went from a store full of shoppers to a ghost town in that time.  I remember when Calvin McDonald was made CEO - many of the staff were excited and believed he was the guy to turn things around.  I remember the talk of hero categories in store meetings and I remember reading about it in the paper.  I also remember being told by management that certain flagship stores (ours was one) would be getting some much needed investment and renovation.  In the end that "reinvestment" amounted to a coat of paint.  When things continued to go wrong and newspaper stories surfaced that our store lease would be sold off, we were assured (both by mgmt in store, and in the press) that this was not so, that Sears was here to stay.  For the sake of the shareholders and those who were laid off, I hope this is more thoroughly investigated.

Comment: Pretty much everything Scott says is already covered in a STEM education:
>a wide subset of characteristics relevant to working with others, thinking critically and being self-aware.
Thinking critically: A STEM degree isn't about teaching Java or MATLAB, the core is teaching critical thinking / engineering methodologies / scientific method.
Working with others: Most STEM programs require students work together in team projects and group labs.
>More academic institutions should consider incorporating course work relevant to the development of human skills, such as emotional intelligence and public speaking
Incorporating course work: Most STEM programs require students take 1-2 "complementary courses" each semester after the first semester. I studied engineering, during which I took sources in psychology and philosophy.
Public speaking: Most STEM programs require students stand in an auditorium and present their projects and research to their class.

Comment: Church buildings are primarily and fundamentally houses of public worship. When I read about architecture students musing about ways in which they might find "new opportunities to define a sacred place in such activities as performing music or making art; in moving their bodies through space in the medium of dance; in digitally connecting with people and events around the globe, etc." I have to wonder if they're not putting the emPHAsis on the wrong syLLAble. 

If they are to fulfill their primary function as serving as worship spaces, it seems to me that church buildings first and foremost ought to express and embody the theology of the gathered faith community. Isn't that what all church buildings are supposed to do? Isn't one of the guiding principles of architecture the axiom that "form follows function?" If the primary function of churches is worship that ought to be THE guiding principle behind any worship space. There was precious little discussion about that in this article.

Comment: Rik, I agree with your comment about overfishing and also suggest we need to try to get a handle on not taking out the forage fish populations which salmon eat.. 
The problem with a retrofit of any construction that's in a national park or on federal land is that you have to bring everything up to current standards. The poorly built Elwha dam had already had serious leak problems in 1912, taking out a bridge downstream. It was rebuilt but serious questions remained about its seismic stability. When Congress voted to take down the dams, attention was paid to their decreasing economic utility and hopes of more fish. The idea that NW WA was going to need reservoirs for drought was just not on the radar in the 1990s. 
Now with the worry about a large quake on the Cascadia fault, the Elwha dams' days would be numbered. Even if only partially breached, the dams potential for property damage and life safety hazard would be considerable. So was it cheaper to take them out or leave them as is?

Comment: Canadians are usually content to preserve their freedom by accepting the limitations of our laws and institutions. This is at the core of our values. In past, people have come to Canada to seek a better life and have readily subscribed to this responsibility. Today, however, people are arriving intent on exploiting or manipulating our laws and institutions rather than supporting them. Comment: "I do acknowledge that wind and solar can only have a limited penetration"

That is not correct.  We can power grids 100% - 24/365 with only wind or solar by adding enough storage.  A 100% solar/storage or 100% wind/storage would not be the most cost efficient solution, but it is possible.

The least expensive way to power our grids is to use a mix of renewable inputs (wind, solar, geothermal, hydro, tidal, biofuel and, possibly, wave and osmotic) along with storage.  The larger and more diverse our 'harvesting area' the less storage we'll need.  And biofuels can be used for dispatchable generation during the infrequent periods of lower wind/solar input.

Do realize that nuclear can have only a limited penetration unless we install enough storage to time-shift output from low demand to high demand periods.  That's why the world has built most of its pump-up hydro storage.  To time-shift nuclear.

It's a bit bitter to know that the lives saved just go on abusing drugs, and likely need those life saving services again and again.  AS I write this I realize,...somewhere, I've lost my compassion for drug users.  I only want less of them,...or less of them around where I live.

Comment: 'Why does the Globe and other media not see the troubles in the middle east as rooted in colonialism?'

Because it isn't? The Shia-Sunni division in Islam goes right back to 632, after the Prophet's death, and the internecine fighting around how best to trace lineage from Muhammed. The decline of the Fatamid Caliphate and the rise of the Umayyad Caliphate was a Sunni victory over a Shia predecessor, and that fighting's still going on today in that region.  Colonialism added some modern salt to an already open wound, but to lay all this violence at the feet of colonialism is myopic.

Where, in your anti-colonialist view, is the Battle of Tours, where Martel defeated the Umayyads, or the Battle of Vienna, where a rag-tag pool of European nobility defeated the Ottomans? You know it was the Ottomans that lost Palestine in WWI, right? Why did the Arab tribes help the British defeat the Ottomans, do you think? To end 600 years of Ottoman rule, perhaps?

Comment: It is extremely unlikely that the auditor's office will find $700K in recurring savings every year to cover its budget. All of the studies showing high return on investment for internal auditing have been done on larger cities with much bigger budgets (LA, Portland, Denver, etc.), hence more potential for savings. This will likely be just another layer of bureaucracy with not much to show for it. It will probably do some good as well, just not to the tune of $700K/year. The person who stands to benefit the most from this measure is whoever gets elected into this position, which is more likely to be a politician than a professional auditor.
